sen.j: 斎王（さいおう、いつきのみこ）は、伊勢神宮または賀茂神社に巫女として奉仕した未婚の内親王または女王 (皇族)。
sen.e: "Saio" or "Itsuki no miko" (the Priestess) was an unmarried princess of the blood or female relative of the Emperor who served as a shirine maiden at the Ise-jingu Shrine and the Kamo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 厳密には内親王なら「斎内親王」、女王の場合は「斎王」「斎女王」と称したが、一般に両者をまとめて斎王と呼ぶ。
sen.e: According to the strict definition, by the name "Sai naishinno" was designated the princess of the blood while the female relative of the Emperor was referred to as "Saio," and in general, they were collectively called "Saio."

sen.j: 伊勢神宮の斎王を斎宮、賀茂神社の斎王を斎院とも称し、斎宮は古代（天武朝）から南北朝時代 (日本)まで、斎院は平安時代から鎌倉時代まで継続した。
sen.e: "Saio" of the Ise -jingu Shrine and "Saio" of the Kamo-jinja Shrine were called "Saigu," and "Saiin" respectively; the former lasted from ancient times (the time of Emperor Tenmu) to the period of the Northern and the Southern Courts (Japan); the latter from the Heian to the Kamakura periods.

sen.j: 賀茂神社では伝統行事として葵祭を行い、斎王が奉仕していた時代は斎王が祭を主宰してきた。
sen.e: As a traditional event, the Kamo-jinja Shrine holds the Aoi Festival, which the Saio presided over during her time of service.

sen.j: その後も葵祭は継続されたが室町、江戸、戦後と三度祭が断絶したという。
sen.e: Since then, the Aoi Festival has continued, but was discontinued three times, in the Muromachi, the Edo, and the post war periods.

sen.j: その後、1953年に祭が復活したことを契機として、1956年の葵祭以降、祭の主役として一般市民から選ばれた未婚の女性を斎王代として祭を開催するようになった。
sen.e: Then, with the revival of the festival in 1953, the Aoi Festival is held in such a way that the role of "Saio dai" has been played by an unmarried woman selected from ordinary citizens since the festival of 1956.

sen.e: The woman selected as "Saio dai," wears "Juni hitoe" or "Karaginumoshozoku" (a layered kimono), putting on stage make up and getting tooth black.
